DOC.HEAD: Pinochet Refuses to Relinquish Army Command
DOC.TEXT: Patricio Aylwin met on Thursday with Augusto Pinochet, whom he will replace as president in March, and said the general refused to give up command of the army. After the 50-minute meeting, the civilian president-elect told reporters he asked Pinochet to consider relinquishing the command, which he cannot be forced to do under the constitution his military regime wrote in 1980. ``I thought it my duty to let him know I considered it preferable that he not make use'' of the special constitutional provisions, Aylwin said. ``He told me the opposite.'' ``The issue was left pending for another conversation,'' Aylwin said. When asked whether he thought Pinochet would change his mind, the president-elect said: ``You'll have to ask him.'' Aylwin, a 71-year-old moderate Christian Democrat supported by a 17-party coalition, won a landslide victory in elections Dec. 14 and will take office March 11th with a new civiilian Congress. He said several other issues were discussed in Thursday's meeting at the presidential palace, including a bill prepared by the ruling junta that would give the military virtual autonomy under civilian rule. Pinochet, 74, made no immediate comment, but Interior Minister Carlos Caceres, who was present at the meeting, gave an account similar to Aylwin's. The general seized power in September 1973, overthrowing President Salvador Allende, an elected Marxist who died in the coup. He was forced to call elections when voters rejected a referendum proposal last year that his presidency be extended to 1997. According to Aylwin, Pinochet said his remaining as commander was ``the best guarantee of the army's loyalty to the constitution and the future government.'' Thursday's meeting was the first known direct conversation since the coup between Pinochet and any leading critic of his authoritarian rule. About 2,000 Aylwin supporters waited outside the palace for his arrival and chanted, ``Give it to him hard!'' as the president-elect entered the building. When some government officials peered through trough gtrgout of windowsped out palace windows, the crowd waved and shouted, ``Go away, Pinochet!'' and ``The dictatorship will fall!'' Aylwin said he and Pinochet they discussed a proposed Armed Forces Law that would bar the new government from cutting the defense budget, limit its influence in promotion of officers and allow the military to decide on arms purchases without government approval. The four-man military junta that acts as a legislature under Pinochet has yet to approve the legislation. Pinochet invited him to prepare written comments on the Armed Forces Law and other issues, ``then our people and people from the government would debate their differences and look for reasonable solutions,'' Aylwin said.
